elements.content: Two new isomorphous three-dimensional porous coordination polymers, {[Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)­(H2O)]·EtOH} n (1) and {[Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)­(H2O)]·2H2O} n (2) [bpe = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane, and H2bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid], have been synthesized by altering the solvent media. Both structures contain one-dimensional channels filled with metal-bound water and guest solvent molecules, and desolvated frameworks show significant changes in structure. However, exposure to the solvent vapors (water and methanol) reverts the structure back to the as-synthesized structure, and thus, the reversible flexible nature of the structure was elucidated. The flexibility and permanent porosity were further reinforced from the CO2 adsorption profiles (195 and 273 K) that show stepwise uptake. Moreover, a high selectivity for O2 over N2 at 77 K was realized. The framework exhibits interesting solvent vapor adsorption behavior with dynamic structural transformation depending upon the size, polarity, and coordination ability of the solvent molecules. Further investigation was conducted by solid state 113Cd nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy that unambiguously advocates the reversible transformation “pentagonal-bipyramidal CdO6N → octahedral CdO5N” geometry in the desolvated state. For the first time, 113Cd NMR has been used as a probe of structural flexibility in a porous coordination polymer system.

elements.content: A Cd­(II)-based flexible framework shows high selectivity toward O2 over N2 at 77 K and stepwise solvent vapor adsorption. The flexibility of the Cd­(II) coordination sphere is studied using the 113Cd solid state NMR technique.

elements.content: There has been an upsurge of interest in the design and synthesis of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with remarkable functions such as a high degree of gas storage and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, ion exchange, molecular sensing, and optoelectronic properties. A large number of rigid and stable functional PCPs have been created by precisely designing the bridging ligands (shape, length, symmetry, and flexibility) and utilizing the versatile coordination of the metal ions. Apart from metal–ligand coordination bonds, H-bonding and π···π interactions between the linkers and between the guest and linker also play a crucial role in determining the final superstructure, stability, and overall functionality of the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There has been an upsurge of interest in the design and synthesis of porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with remarkable functions such as a high degree of gas storage and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, ion exchange, molecular sensing, and optoelectronic properties. A large number of rigid and stable functional PCPs have been created by precisely designing the bridging ligands (shape, length, symmetry, and flexibility) and utilizing the versatile coordination of the metal ions. Apart from metal-ligand coordination bonds, H-bonding and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the linkers and between the guest and linker also play a crucial role in determining the final superstructure, stability, and overall functionality of the framework.

elements.content: In general, PCPs consist of repeated building units and provide uniform open spaces filled with guest molecules. Because of such regularities, in PCPs extensive cooperativity would be expected among the molecules throughout the crystal, such that the small distortion/change around a metal center induces the overall framework’s rearrangements in a well-concerted fashion to maintain its macroscopic integrity. Several unique framework transformations induced by adsorption/desorption of guest molecules have been reported and highlighted, and in number of cases, direct determination of the second structure through single-crystal-to-single-crystal structure transformation clarified the whole phenomenon, although there are difficulties in interpreting the phenomenon related to guest-induced structural transformation without proper structural information about second phases. Nevertheless, the spectroscopy measurements would be a potential tool for understanding the guest-induced structural transformation. In particular, metal ion-based nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) studies would be sensitive to change in geometry and will be beneficial for gaining structural insights, but such studies are yet to be properly explored in PCP chemistry. On the other hand, separation of gases, particularly O2 from air, is useful for oxyfuel combustion, and this is another possible approach to reducing CO2 in the atmosphere. On an industrial scale, cryogenic methods are employed to separate O2, but those are not cost-effective. Hence, a cheaper adsorption-based separation is in demand, and PCP can be a potential candidate for the same. There have been few reports of PCP material that showed O2 versus N2 selectivity. On the basis of these backgrounds, we have focused on constructing porous frameworks by selecting Cd2+ as a metal node. Taking into account the d10 electronic configuration and flexible and versatile coordination geometry of Cd2+, we have aimed to synthesize a microporous framework of Cd2+ using a mixed linker system. Here, solid state 113Cd NMR spectroscopy is exploited as a probe to understand the changes in Cd2+ environment during guest-induced structural change. This work reports the synthesis, structural characterization, unique sorption properties, and selectivity of three-dimensional (3D) microporous frameworks, {[Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)­(H2O)]·EtOH} n (1) and {[Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)­(H2O)]·2H2O} n (2) [bpe = 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane, and bdc = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid]. In 1, the Cd2+ geometry shows a reversible change from pentagonal bipyramidal (heptacoordinate) to octahedral (hexacoordinate) upon desolvation and resolvation. The change in the geometry of Cd2+ influences pore deformation, which is realized through X-ray diffraction (XRD) and solid state 113Cd NMR studies. Interestingly, we observed that the desolvated structure shows highly selective adsorption of O2 over N2 at 77 K and also a two-step uptake of CO2 at 195 and 273 K. Such O2 selectivity and also the unique CO2 adsorption are very important in many aspects of separation techniques. Moreover, we observed unique stepwise solvent vapor (H2O and MeOH) adsorption profiles and also a size exclusion effect of the desolvated framework. The structural change with methanol also corroborated with 113Cd NMR studies.

elements.content: All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. Cd­(ClO4)2·H2O and 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane were obtained from Aldrich Co., and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid was obtained from Tokyo Kasei Industrial. Elemental analysis was conducted on a Flash EA 1112 series, Thermo Finnigan instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was conducted with a Rigaku Instrument TG8120 apparatus in a nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were collected on a Rigaku RINT-2200HF diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The obtained PXRD pattern for 1a (desolvated 1) was indexed with TREOR 90. Cell parameters of 1a were as follows: triclinic, a = 9.322(9) Å, b = 7.157(5) Å, c = 10.69(2) Å, α = 100.8(1)°, β = 103.8(8)°, γ = 94.2(1)°, V = 675.16 Å3.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. Cd(ClO4)2⋅H2O and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane were obtained from Aldrich Co., and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid was obtained from Tokyo Kasei Industrial. Elemental analysis was conducted on a Flash EA 1112 series, Thermo Finnigan instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was conducted with a Rigaku Instrument TG8120 apparatus in a nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were collected on a Rigaku RINT-2200HF diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The obtained PXRD pattern for 1a (desolvated 1) was indexed with TREOR 90. Cell parameters of 1a were as follows: triclinic, a = 9.322(9) Å, b = 7.157(5) Å, c = 10.69(2) Å, α = 100.8(1)°, β = 103.8(8)°, γ = 94.2(1)°, V = 675.16 Å3.

elements.content: A 50 mL aqueous solution of Cd­(II) was prepared by dissolving Cd­(ClO4)2·H2O (1 mmol, 0.311 g), and 50 mL of a ligand solution was prepared by mixing the 25 mL ethanol solution of bpe (0.5 mmol, 0.91 g) and the 25 mL aqueous solution of Na2bdc (1 mmol, 0.210 g). Then 2 mL of the ligand solution was carefully layered above the 2 mL metal solution using the 0.5 mL buffer solution [2:1 (v/v) H2O:EtOH]. The colorless square crystals suitable for X-ray single-crystal structure determination were obtained after one month. The crystals were separated and washed with a MeOH/H2O (1:1) mixture and dried (80% yield). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H18CdNO6: C, 44.40; H, 4.16; N, 3.23. Found: C, 43.20; H, 3.67; N, 3.23. FT-IR (KBr pellet, 4000–400 cm–1): 3450, 1591, 1557, 1370, 1406, 1211, 1021.

elements.content: The adsorption isotherms of N2 (77 K), CO2 (195 and 273 K), and different solvent vapors (H2O, MeOH, and EtOH) were measured using BELSORP-18-Plus volumetric adsorption equipment from BEL (Osaka, Japan). In the sample chamber (17.5 mL) was placed the adsorbent sample (100–150 mg), which was prepared at 423 K under vacuum (10–1 Pa) for ∼5 h prior to measurement of the isotherms. The adsorbate was placed into the sample tube, and then the change in pressure was monitored and the degree of adsorption determined by the decrease in the pressure at the equilibrium state. Helium gas at a certain pressure was introduced into the gas chamber and was allowed to diffuse into the sample chamber by opening a valve. The change in pressure allowed an accurate determination of the volume of the total gas phase. The change in pressure was monitored in a similar manner by using a guest vapor in place of helium. The amount of guest adsorbed was calculated readily from the pressure difference (P cal – P e), where P cal is the calculated pressure with no guest adsorption and P e is the observed equilibrium pressure. All operations were computer-controlled and automatic.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Measurement

The adsorption isotherms of N2 (77 K), CO2 (195 and 273 K), and different solvent vapors (H2O, MeOH, and EtOH) were measured using BELSORP-18-Plus volumetric adsorption equipment from BEL (Osaka, Japan). In the sample chamber (17.5 mL) was placed the adsorbent sample (100-150 mg), which was prepared at 423 K under vacuum (10-1 Pa) for ~5 h prior to measurement of the isotherms. The adsorbate was placed into the sample tube, and then the change in pressure was monitored and the degree of adsorption determined by the decrease in the pressure at the equilibrium state. Helium gas at a certain pressure was introduced into the gas chamber and was allowed to diffuse into the sample chamber by opening a valve. The change in pressure allowed an accurate determination of the volume of the total gas phase. The change in pressure was monitored in a similar manner by using a guest vapor in place of helium. The amount of guest adsorbed was calculated readily from the pressure difference (P cal - P e), where P cal is the calculated pressure with no guest adsorption and P e is the observed equilibrium pressure. All operations were computer-controlled and automatic.

elements.content: All NMR experiments were conducted on a Bruker ADVANCE 400 MHz spectrometer operating at a resonance frequency of 88.754 MHz for 113Cd at room temperature. A 7 mm MAS probe was used at spinning speeds of 6 kHz. The cross-polarization magic-angle spinning (CPMAS) method was used to improve the sensitivity and resolution of the spectra. A 2 ms contact time for CP and a recycle delay of 5 s were used. 113Cd chemical shifts were referenced indirectly to Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (−102.2 ppm).
elements.clean_text:
Solid State NMR Spectroscopy

All NMR experiments were conducted on a Bruker ADVANCE 400 MHz spectrometer operating at a resonance frequency of 88.754 MHz for 113Cd at room temperature. A 7 mm MAS probe was used at spinning speeds of 6 kHz. The cross-polarization magic-angle spinning (CPMAS) method was used to improve the sensitivity and resolution of the spectra. A 2 ms contact time for CP and a recycle delay of 5 s were used. 113Cd chemical shifts were referenced indirectly to Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (-102.2 ppm).

elements.content: For each of 1 and 2, a suitable single crystal was mounted on a glass fiber and coated with epoxy resin, and X-ray data were recorded on a Rigaku Mercury diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) and a CCD two-dimensional (2D) detector. In both cases, the sizes of the unit cells were calculated from the reflections collected on the setting angles of seven frames by changing 0.5° for each frame. Three different settings were used and were changed by 0.5°/frame, and intensity data were collected with a scan width of 0.5°. Empirical absorption correction by using REQABA was performed for all data in both cases. The structures of both 1 and 2 were determined by direct methods by using SIR-97 and expanded by using Fourier techniques. All calculations were conducted with the teXsan crystallographic software package from Molecular Structure Corp. For both compounds, the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and all hydrogen atoms placed in the ideal positions. For compound 1 the ethanol guest molecule atoms (O6, C15, and C16) and for compound 2 the H2O molecules (O6 and O7) were refined isotropically. Potential solvent accessible area and void space were calculated using the PLATON multipurpose crystallographic software. All crystallographic and refinement parameters for both complexes are summarized in . CCDC 1034955 and 1034956 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determination

For each of 1 and 2, a suitable single crystal was mounted on a glass fiber and coated with epoxy resin, and X-ray data were recorded on a Rigaku Mercury diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71069 Å) and a CCD two-dimensional (2D) detector. In both cases, the sizes of the unit cells were calculated from the reflections collected on the setting angles of seven frames by changing 0.5° for each frame. Three different settings were used and were changed by 0.5°/frame, and intensity data were collected with a scan width of 0.5°. Empirical absorption correction by using REQABA was performed for all data in both cases. The structures of both 1 and 2 were determined by direct methods by using SIR-97 and expanded by using Fourier techniques. All calculations were conducted with the teXsan crystallographic software package from Molecular Structure Corp. For both compounds, the non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically and all hydrogen atoms placed in the ideal positions. For compound 1 the ethanol guest molecule atoms (O6, C15, and C16) and for compound 2 the H2O molecules (O6 and O7) were refined isotropically. Potential solvent accessible area and void space were calculated using the PLATON multipurpose crystallographic software. All crystallographic and refinement parameters for both complexes are summarized in . CCDC 1034955 and 1034956 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrated that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group and is a 3D porous coordination polymer containing heptacoordinated Cd2+ centers ( and ). Each heptacoordinated Cd2+ metal center is connected to three different bdc linkers through carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2–O5), one bpe (N1), and one H2O molecule (O1), residing in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal environment (). Interestingly, the carboxylate group (O2 and O3) of one of the bdc linkers acts as a chelating bidentate ligand, and the other (O4 and O5) functions as a chelating as well as μ-oxo bridging ligand. Therefore, each bdc linker acts as a bridging tridentate ligand. Such a type of ligation creates a Cd2(μ-O)2 cluster, acting as a secondary building unit (SBU) in the structure. Each of these SBUs is connected to four other SBUs by four bdc linkers to generate two-dimensional rectangular sheets lying on the crystallographic ab plane (a). Such 2D sheets are connected by the bpe linkers to form a 3D microporous framework having one-dimensional channels along the c-axis (dimensions of 5.4 Å × 4.4 Å) (b,c). These 1D channels are occupied by the ethanol molecules that are in the proximity of the coordinated (O1) water molecules and thus form strong H-bonds [O1­(w)···O6­(EtOH), 2.717(7) Å] (Figure S1). The H-bonding interactions play a very essential role in the overall conformation and stability of the 3D microporous framework. The Cd2+–O and Cd2+–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.273(5)–2.672(6) and 2.283(5) Å, respectively (Table S1). The degree of distortion from an ideal pentagonal bipyramidal geometry is reflected in the transoid and cisoid angles, which are 133.09(9)–169.91(9)° and 51.90(9)–114.12(9)°, respectively. The deviation of Cd2+ from the mean plane formed by the equatorial atoms is 0.311(2) Å, and the maximal deviation of the equatorial oxygen atom is 0.803(1) Å. The void volume calculated after removal of the coordinated and guest solvent molecules was found to be 22.0% of the total cell volume. Topology analysis by TOPOS shows a binodal (2,6)-connected net with Schläfi symbol {812.123}­{8}­3 (d).

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description of {[Cd(bpe)0.5(bdc)(H2O)]⋅EtOH} n  (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrated that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group and is a 3D porous coordination polymer containing heptacoordinated Cd2+ centers ( and ). Each heptacoordinated Cd2+ metal center is connected to three different bdc linkers through carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2-O5), one bpe (N1), and one H2O molecule (O1), residing in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal environment (). Interestingly, the carboxylate group (O2 and O3) of one of the bdc linkers acts as a chelating bidentate ligand, and the other (O4 and O5) functions as a chelating as well as μ-oxo bridging ligand. Therefore, each bdc linker acts as a bridging tridentate ligand. Such a type of ligation creates a Cd2(μ-O)2 cluster, acting as a secondary building unit (SBU) in the structure. Each of these SBUs is connected to four other SBUs by four bdc linkers to generate two-dimensional rectangular sheets lying on the crystallographic ab plane (a). Such 2D sheets are connected by the bpe linkers to form a 3D microporous framework having one-dimensional channels along the c-axis (dimensions of 5.4 Å × 4.4 Å) (b,c). These 1D channels are occupied by the ethanol molecules that are in the proximity of the coordinated (O1) water molecules and thus form strong H-bonds [O1(w)⋅⋅⋅O6(EtOH), 2.717(7) Å] (Figure S1). The H-bonding interactions play a very essential role in the overall conformation and stability of the 3D microporous framework. The Cd2+-O and Cd2+-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.273(5)-2.672(6) and 2.283(5) Å, respectively (Table S1). The degree of distortion from an ideal pentagonal bipyramidal geometry is reflected in the transoid and cisoid angles, which are 133.09(9)-169.91(9)° and 51.90(9)-114.12(9)°, respectively. The deviation of Cd2+ from the mean plane formed by the equatorial atoms is 0.311(2) Å, and the maximal deviation of the equatorial oxygen atom is 0.803(1) Å. The void volume calculated after removal of the coordinated and guest solvent molecules was found to be 22.0% of the total cell volume. Topology analysis by TOPOS shows a binodal (2,6)-connected net with Schläfi symbol {812.123}{8}3 (d).

elements.content: Compound 2 is iso-structural to compound 1, having an identical SBU. The microporous channels of 2 are identical to those of 1, but the guest ethanol molecule is replaced by two water molecules. The guest H2O molecules are H-bonded to O1w of the wall [O1w···O­(H2O), 2.701(14) Å] (Figure S2). In addition, the guest H2O molecules are H-bonded to each other [distances, 2.790(14), 2.844(14) Å], forming a 1D H2O column along the c-direction. The void space calculated after removal of coordinated and guest water molecules is 22.0%, identical to that of compound 1.
elements.clean_text:
Description of the Crystal Structure of {[Cd(bpe)0.5(bdc)(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (2)

Compound 2 is iso-structural to compound 1, having an identical SBU. The microporous channels of 2 are identical to those of 1, but the guest ethanol molecule is replaced by two water molecules. The guest H2O molecules are H-bonded to O1w of the wall [O1w⋅⋅⋅O(H2O), 2.701(14) Å] (Figure S2). In addition, the guest H2O molecules are H-bonded to each other [distances, 2.790(14), 2.844(14) Å], forming a 1D H2O column along the c-direction. The void space calculated after removal of coordinated and guest water molecules is 22.0%, identical to that of compound 1.

elements.content: From the TG analysis of compound 1, we found that the guest ethanol and coordinated water molecules can be completely removed at ∼80 °C (observed, 14.3%; calculated, 14.8%), and after removal of solvents, the resultant {Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)} n (3) is stable up to 290 °C (Figure S3). Further heating gradually decomposes the compound. In the case of compound 2 also, the guest and coordinated solvent molecules are removed at 80 °C (observed, 11.6%; calculated, 12.8%) (Figure S3).
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Stability

From the TG analysis of compound 1, we found that the guest ethanol and coordinated water molecules can be completely removed at ~80 °C (observed, 14.3%; calculated, 14.8%), and after removal of solvents, the resultant {Cd(bpe)0.5(bdc)} n  (3) is stable up to 290 °C (Figure S3). Further heating gradually decomposes the compound. In the case of compound 2 also, the guest and coordinated solvent molecules are removed at 80 °C (observed, 11.6%; calculated, 12.8%) (Figure S3).

elements.content: To understand the framework stability upon desolvation, PXRD measurements were taken, and these revealed interesting structural changes. Compound 1 was completely desolvated at 100 °C under vacuum to generate {Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)} (1a). The X-ray diffraction peaks obtained from 1a were sharp, indicating the crystalline nature of the desolvated phase, but those are different compared to that of 1 (). Indexing of the obtained PXRD pattern of 1a shows a clear change in the cell parameters. The total cell volume decreases from 844(3) to 675.16 Å3, indicating an obvious contraction of the structure. In addition, the peak corresponding to (001) and (100) planes at 8.96° and 10.22° of as-synthesized 1 has shifted to smaller angles of 8.67° and 9.85°, respectively, in 1a ( and ). When compound 1a was exposed to vapors of methanol, it generates a framework structure similar to that of 1, as can be seen from the PXRD patterns. This shows that the structure is dynamic in nature and also reveals the reversible structural transformation. Further, exposure to the vapors of ethanol, water, acetonitrile, and THF shows that the structure again reverts back to a structure similar to that of compound 1 (Figure S4).

elements.content: To check the porous property of compound 1a, N2, O2 (77 K), and CO2 (195 K) gas adsorption measurements were taken. Although compound 1a contains sufficient window dimensions to allow the diffusion of N2 (3.64 Å), it shows a very small amount of N2 uptake (25 mL at 101.325 kPa) at 77 K (a). This is probably due to a higher diffusion barrier imposed on the 1D channel after desolvation and the corresponding structural contraction. It is noteworthy that measurement of O2 at 77 K reveals the steep uptake in low-pressure regions and saturates at ∼20 kPa with an uptake amount of 87 mL/g (∼12.43 wt %) (a). This suggests that the framework is microporous in nature. The final uptake amount of N2 at ∼20 kPa is only 1.5 wt %. Such a huge uptake difference (selectivity factor of ∼10) in a low-relative pressure region makes this framework highly selective toward O2 over N2. The amounts of adsorption of N2 and O2 per Cd2+ atom calculated from the Langmuir analyses are 0.3 and 1.3, respectively. Apart from preferential O2 adsorption over N2, the CO2 (kinetic diameter of ∼3.4 Å) adsorption profile at 195 K shows interesting features (b). The isotherm shows a two-step uptake and also a distinct hysteresis in adsorption and desorption profile. There are two steps at relative pressures of 0.05 and 0.12 as realized from a logarithmic scale plot, and at P/P 0 ∼ 0.96, the final uptake amount is 75 mL/g. In addition, at 273 K CO2 uptake profile also shows a distinct stepwise uptake with a final uptake amount of 23 mL/g (Figure S5). This stepwise adsorption again reflects the structural flexibility associated with CO2 adsorption as the CO2 molecule can interact with the pore surface decorated with carboxylate oxygen and an aromatic π-cloud from bpe and bdc linkers. This type of stepwise uptake of CO2 is not very common and also very important in terms of separation purposes.
elements.clean_text:
Permanent Porosity: Selective Sorption of O2 over N2 

To check the porous property of compound 1a, N2, O2 (77 K), and CO2 (195 K) gas adsorption measurements were taken. Although compound 1a contains sufficient window dimensions to allow the diffusion of N2 (3.64 Å), it shows a very small amount of N2 uptake (25 mL at 101.325 kPa) at 77 K (a). This is probably due to a higher diffusion barrier imposed on the 1D channel after desolvation and the corresponding structural contraction. It is noteworthy that measurement of O2 at 77 K reveals the steep uptake in low-pressure regions and saturates at ~20 kPa with an uptake amount of 87 mL/g (~12.43 wt %) (a). This suggests that the framework is microporous in nature. The final uptake amount of N2 at ~20 kPa is only 1.5 wt %. Such a huge uptake difference (selectivity factor of ~10) in a low-relative pressure region makes this framework highly selective toward O2 over N2. The amounts of adsorption of N2 and O2 per Cd2+ atom calculated from the Langmuir analyses are 0.3 and 1.3, respectively. Apart from preferential O2 adsorption over N2, the CO2 (kinetic diameter of ~3.4 Å) adsorption profile at 195 K shows interesting features (b). The isotherm shows a two-step uptake and also a distinct hysteresis in adsorption and desorption profile. There are two steps at relative pressures of 0.05 and 0.12 as realized from a logarithmic scale plot, and at P/P 0 ~ 0.96, the final uptake amount is 75 mL/g. In addition, at 273 K CO2 uptake profile also shows a distinct stepwise uptake with a final uptake amount of 23 mL/g (Figure S5). This stepwise adsorption again reflects the structural flexibility associated with CO2 adsorption as the CO2 molecule can interact with the pore surface decorated with carboxylate oxygen and an aromatic π-cloud from bpe and bdc linkers. This type of stepwise uptake of CO2 is not very common and also very important in terms of separation purposes.

elements.content: The permanent porosity of 1a and structural transformation observed upon exposure to water, methanol, and other solvents lead us to see the vapor adsorption properties of 1a. An interesting uptake profile was observed for MeOH at 293 K (a). During the initial adsorption process, the isotherm shows a type I curve and then suddenly rises at point A (P/P 0 ∼ 0.39) and attains a saturated level at point B (P/P 0 ∼ 0.92). In the desorption process, MeOH molecules are gradually released until point C (P/P 0 ∼ 0.08), and then the desorption drops immediately; thus, the adsorption/desorption isotherm shows a large hysteresis curve. The amounts of MeOH molecules adsorbed per Cd2+ in the framework are approximately 0.82 (point A), 2.45 (point B), and 1.69 (point C) (b). The initial type I uptake can be considered as the coordination of methanol to the Cd2+ center, and thus, a structural transformation occurs because of conversion of CdO5N to CdO5N­(MeOH). After point A, additional MeOH molecules fill the pore as guest molecules. The desorption is accompanied by a structural change based on the release of loosely bound and coordinated MeOH molecules, and thus, a large hysteresis or different desorption path can be correlated to the structural change and corresponding barrier during the desorption of MeOH molecules. At 298 K, the water vapor adsorption profile of 1a shows a type I profile until P/P 0 ∼ 0.45 with an uptake amount 65 mL/g (∼1.07 molecules/formula), and after that, it rises sharply to reach a final uptake amount of 292 mL/g (4.84 molecules/formula) (b). The first step clearly indicates that the water molecule coordinates to the metal center, and this leads to transformation of the CdO5N → CdO6N core. In the second step, water molecules fill the pores and probably form hydrogen-bonded clusters. The desorption path clearly makes a hysteresis loop because of strong hydrogen bond association of the water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Solvent Vapor Adsorption

The permanent porosity of 1a and structural transformation observed upon exposure to water, methanol, and other solvents lead us to see the vapor adsorption properties of 1a. An interesting uptake profile was observed for MeOH at 293 K (a). During the initial adsorption process, the isotherm shows a type I curve and then suddenly rises at point A (P/P 0 ~ 0.39) and attains a saturated level at point B (P/P 0 ~ 0.92). In the desorption process, MeOH molecules are gradually released until point C (P/P 0 ~ 0.08), and then the desorption drops immediately; thus, the adsorption/desorption isotherm shows a large hysteresis curve. The amounts of MeOH molecules adsorbed per Cd2+ in the framework are approximately 0.82 (point A), 2.45 (point B), and 1.69 (point C) (b). The initial type I uptake can be considered as the coordination of methanol to the Cd2+ center, and thus, a structural transformation occurs because of conversion of CdO5N to CdO5N(MeOH). After point A, additional MeOH molecules fill the pore as guest molecules. The desorption is accompanied by a structural change based on the release of loosely bound and coordinated MeOH molecules, and thus, a large hysteresis or different desorption path can be correlated to the structural change and corresponding barrier during the desorption of MeOH molecules. At 298 K, the water vapor adsorption profile of 1a shows a type I profile until P/P 0 ~ 0.45 with an uptake amount 65 mL/g (~1.07 molecules/formula), and after that, it rises sharply to reach a final uptake amount of 292 mL/g (4.84 molecules/formula) (b). The first step clearly indicates that the water molecule coordinates to the metal center, and this leads to transformation of the CdO5N → CdO6N core. In the second step, water molecules fill the pores and probably form hydrogen-bonded clusters. The desorption path clearly makes a hysteresis loop because of strong hydrogen bond association of the water molecules.

elements.content: The structural changes realized from the PXRD experiments suggest that the framework is dynamic in nature and exhibit reversible guest responsive behavior. To elucidate the solvent-induced change in the metal ion geometry, we have used 113Cd NMR spectroscopy as a probe. 113Cd NMR shows considerable promise as a probe of metal ion environments with chemical shifts in the range of ∼900 ppm. 113Cd CPMAS NMR spectra for as-synthesized 1, 1a, and methanol-exposed 1a are shown in . The isotropic 113Cd shift in 1 is 5.0 ppm (). As mentioned previously, the Cd2+ center in 1 is heptacoordinated with the distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with a CdO6N core. Because the chemical shift of heptacoordinated Cd2+ with CdO7 core remains in the range of 0–60 ppm, the shift at 5.0 ppm is reasonable, resulting in a downfield shift due to the deshielding by the N atom of the bpe ligand. Interestingly, in the case of 1a, an isotropic chemical shift is observed at 58.0 ppm with a small shoulder peak at 50 ppm, which is quite different from that of 1. This lower field signals are due to the geometry change of Cd2+, “pentagonal-bipyramidal CdO6N (1) → octahedral CdO5N (3)”, because the coordinated H2O molecule is removed. The isotropic Cd2+ shifts with the CdO6 and CdN6 core are observed in the ranges of 150 to 0 ppm and 200–380 ppm, respectively. The main peak with a small shoulder would suggest that 1a has an octahedral coordination environment with a CdO5N core. However, it is difficult to address the isotropic shifts further as the Cd2+ is coordinated to the mixed N and O atoms, and the polyhedron around Cd2+ is a distorted octahedron. Importantly, the isotropic shift observed for Cd2+ in methanol-exposed compound 3 is 4.0 ppm, which is close to that of 1. Hence, one can conclude that the hexacoordinated metal center is again heptacoordinated upon exposure to solvent vapor. Upon exposure to methanol vapor, a new heptacoordinated core CdO5N­(MeOH) is obtained, which is structurally similar to that of 1, as shown by the MeOH-exposed PXRD pattern of 1a. Therefore, for the first time, the solvent-induced structural flexibility and reversibility of the framework have been probed by 113Cd NMR spectroscopy.
elements.clean_text:
Solvent-Induced Structural Change: 113Cd NMR as a Probe

The structural changes realized from the PXRD experiments suggest that the framework is dynamic in nature and exhibit reversible guest responsive behavior. To elucidate the solvent-induced change in the metal ion geometry, we have used 113Cd NMR spectroscopy as a probe. 113Cd NMR shows considerable promise as a probe of metal ion environments with chemical shifts in the range of ~900 ppm. 113Cd CPMAS NMR spectra for as-synthesized 1, 1a, and methanol-exposed 1a are shown in . The isotropic 113Cd shift in 1 is 5.0 ppm (). As mentioned previously, the Cd2+ center in 1 is heptacoordinated with the distorted pentagonal bipyramidal geometry with a CdO6N core. Because the chemical shift of heptacoordinated Cd2+ with CdO7 core remains in the range of 0-60 ppm, the shift at 5.0 ppm is reasonable, resulting in a downfield shift due to the deshielding by the N atom of the bpe ligand. Interestingly, in the case of 1a, an isotropic chemical shift is observed at 58.0 ppm with a small shoulder peak at 50 ppm, which is quite different from that of 1. This lower field signals are due to the geometry change of Cd2+, "pentagonal-bipyramidal CdO6N (1) → octahedral CdO5N (3)", because the coordinated H2O molecule is removed. The isotropic Cd2+ shifts with the CdO6 and CdN6 core are observed in the ranges of 150 to 0 ppm and 200-380 ppm, respectively. The main peak with a small shoulder would suggest that 1a has an octahedral coordination environment with a CdO5N core. However, it is difficult to address the isotropic shifts further as the Cd2+ is coordinated to the mixed N and O atoms, and the polyhedron around Cd2+ is a distorted octahedron. Importantly, the isotropic shift observed for Cd2+ in methanol-exposed compound 3 is 4.0 ppm, which is close to that of 1. Hence, one can conclude that the hexacoordinated metal center is again heptacoordinated upon exposure to solvent vapor. Upon exposure to methanol vapor, a new heptacoordinated core CdO5N(MeOH) is obtained, which is structurally similar to that of 1, as shown by the MeOH-exposed PXRD pattern of 1a. Therefore, for the first time, the solvent-induced structural flexibility and reversibility of the framework have been probed by 113Cd NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have synthesized two Cd2+-based 3D PCPs, {[Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)­(H2O)]·EtOH} n (1) and {[Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)­(H2O)]·2H2O} n (2), which differ only in terms of solvent molecules. Removal of coordinated solvent molecules causes a drastic change in the framework, and this has been characterized by a solid state 113Cd NMR probe that confirms the transformation of the CdO5N → CdO6N core. The desolvated framework shows preferential adsorption of O2 over N2 at 77 K, and this property makes it a promising material for N2/O2 separation. The CO2 adsorption isotherm at 195 K shows a two-step adsorption process, which again reveals the flexible characteristics of the framework. Further, the water and methanol solvent vapor adsorption profiles show unique characteristics indicating the reversible structural changes during the adsorption process and confirm the spectroscopic observation. Such spectroscopic characterization of metal ion geometry could open up a new path for characterization of flexible PCPs and their guest responsive behavior, and this can have huge implications for catalysis (e.g., Lewis acid catalyst) and separation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have synthesized two Cd2+-based 3D PCPs, {[Cd(bpe)0.5(bdc)(H2O)]⋅EtOH} n  (1) and {[Cd(bpe)0.5(bdc)(H2O)]⋅2H2O} n  (2), which differ only in terms of solvent molecules. Removal of coordinated solvent molecules causes a drastic change in the framework, and this has been characterized by a solid state 113Cd NMR probe that confirms the transformation of the CdO5N → CdO6N core. The desolvated framework shows preferential adsorption of O2 over N2 at 77 K, and this property makes it a promising material for N2/O2 separation. The CO2 adsorption isotherm at 195 K shows a two-step adsorption process, which again reveals the flexible characteristics of the framework. Further, the water and methanol solvent vapor adsorption profiles show unique characteristics indicating the reversible structural changes during the adsorption process and confirm the spectroscopic observation. Such spectroscopic characterization of metal ion geometry could open up a new path for characterization of flexible PCPs and their guest responsive behavior, and this can have huge implications for catalysis (e.g., Lewis acid catalyst) and separation.

A 50 mL aqueous solution of Cd­(II) was prepared by dissolving Cd­(ClO4)2·H2O (1 mmol, 0.311 g), and 50 mL of a ligand solution was prepared by mixing the 25 mL ethanol solution of bpe (0.5 mmol, 0.91 g) and the 25 mL aqueous solution of Na2bdc (1 mmol, 0.210 g). Then 2 mL of the ligand solution was carefully layered above the 2 mL metal solution using the 0.5 mL buffer solution [2:1 (v/v) H2O:EtOH]. The colorless square crystals suitable for X-ray single-crystal structure determination were obtained after one month. The crystals were separated and washed with a MeOH/H2O (1:1) mixture and dried (80% yield). Elemental analysis calculated for C16H18CdNO6: C, 44.40; H, 4.16; N, 3.23. Found: C, 43.20; H, 3.67; N, 3.23. FT-IR (KBr pellet, 4000–400 cm–1): 3450, 1591, 1557, 1370, 1406, 1211, 1021.

Complex 2 was prepared by adopting the same procedure used for 1, by changing the MeOH solvent instead of ethanol (70% yield). Elemental analysis calcd for C14H16CdNO7: C, 42.42; H, 3.78; N, 3.33. cln_elements.content:
All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. Cd­(ClO4)2·H2O and 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethane were obtained from Aldrich Co., and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid was obtained from Tokyo Kasei Industrial. Elemental analysis was conducted on a Flash EA 1112 series, Thermo Finnigan instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was conducted with a Rigaku Instrument TG8120 apparatus in a nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were collected on a Rigaku RINT-2200HF diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The obtained PXRD pattern for 1a (desolvated 1) was indexed with TREOR 90. Cell parameters of 1a were as follows: triclinic, a = 9.322(9) Å, b = 7.157(5) Å, c = 10.69(2) Å, α = 100.8(1)°, β = 103.8(8)°, γ = 94.2(1)°, V = 675.16 Å3.

Results and DiscussionCrystal Structure Description of {[Cd­(bpe)<sub>0.5</sub>(bdc)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]·EtOH}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrated that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group and is a 3D porous coordination polymer containing heptacoordinated Cd2+ centers ( and ). Each heptacoordinated Cd2+ metal center is connected to three different bdc linkers through carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2–O5), one bpe (N1), and one H2O molecule (O1), residing in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal environment (). Interestingly, the carboxylate group (O2 and O3) of one of the bdc linkers acts as a chelating bidentate ligand, and the other (O4 and O5) functions as a chelating as well as μ-oxo bridging ligand. Therefore, each bdc linker acts as a bridging tridentate ligand. Such a type of ligation creates a Cd2(μ-O)2 cluster, acting as a secondary building unit (SBU) in the structure. Each of these SBUs is connected to four other SBUs by four bdc linkers to generate two-dimensional rectangular sheets lying on the crystallographic ab plane (a). Such 2D sheets are connected by the bpe linkers to form a 3D microporous framework having one-dimensional channels along the c-axis (dimensions of 5.4 Å × 4.4 Å) (b,c). These 1D channels are occupied by the ethanol molecules that are in the proximity of the coordinated (O1) water molecules and thus form strong H-bonds [O1­(w)···O6­(EtOH), 2.717(7) Å] (Figure S1). The H-bonding interactions play a very essential role in the overall conformation and stability of the 3D microporous framework. The Cd2+–O and Cd2+–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.273(5)–2.672(6) and 2.283(5) Å, respectively (Table S1). The degree of distortion from an ideal pentagonal bipyramidal geometry is reflected in the transoid and cisoid angles, which are 133.09(9)–169.91(9)° and 51.90(9)–114.12(9)°, respectively. The deviation of Cd2+ from the mean plane formed by the equatorial atoms is 0.311(2) Å, and the maximal deviation of the equatorial oxygen atom is 0.803(1) Å. The void volume calculated after removal of the coordinated and guest solvent molecules was found to be 22.0% of the total cell volume. Topology analysis by TOPOS shows a binodal (2,6)-connected net with Schläfi symbol {812.123}­{8}­3 (d).

Thermal Stability

From the TG analysis of compound 1, we found that the guest ethanol and coordinated water molecules can be completely removed at ∼80 °C (observed, 14.3%; calculated, 14.8%), and after removal of solvents, the resultant {Cd­(bpe)0.5(bdc)} n (3) is stable up to 290 °C (Figure S3). Further heating gradually decomposes the compound. In the case of compound 2 also, the guest and coordinated solvent molecules are removed at 80 °C (observed, 11.6%; calculated, 12.8%) (Figure S3).

Permanent Porosity: Selective Sorption of O<sub>2</sub> over N<sub>2</sub>

To check the porous property of compound 1a, N2, O2 (77 K), and CO2 (195 K) gas adsorption measurements were taken. Although compound 1a contains sufficient window dimensions to allow the diffusion of N2 (3.64 Å), it shows a very small amount of N2 uptake (25 mL at 101.325 kPa) at 77 K (a). This is probably due to a higher diffusion barrier imposed on the 1D channel after desolvation and the corresponding structural contraction. It is noteworthy that measurement of O2 at 77 K reveals the steep uptake in low-pressure regions and saturates at ∼20 kPa with an uptake amount of 87 mL/g (∼12.43 wt %) (a). This suggests that the framework is microporous in nature. The final uptake amount of N2 at ∼20 kPa is only 1.5 wt %. Such a huge uptake difference (selectivity factor of ∼10) in a low-relative pressure region makes this framework highly selective toward O2 over N2. The amounts of adsorption of N2 and O2 per Cd2+ atom calculated from the Langmuir analyses are 0.3 and 1.3, respectively. Apart from preferential O2 adsorption over N2, the CO2 (kinetic diameter of ∼3.4 Å) adsorption profile at 195 K shows interesting features (b). The isotherm shows a two-step uptake and also a distinct hysteresis in adsorption and desorption profile. There are two steps at relative pressures of 0.05 and 0.12 as realized from a logarithmic scale plot, and at P/P 0 ∼ 0.96, the final uptake amount is 75 mL/g. In addition, at 273 K CO2 uptake profile also shows a distinct stepwise uptake with a final uptake amount of 23 mL/g (Figure S5). This stepwise adsorption again reflects the structural flexibility associated with CO2 adsorption as the CO2 molecule can interact with the pore surface decorated with carboxylate oxygen and an aromatic π-cloud from bpe and bdc linkers. This type of stepwise uptake of CO2 is not very common and also very important in terms of separation purposes.

Solvent Vapor Adsorption

The permanent porosity of 1a and structural transformation observed upon exposure to water, methanol, and other solvents lead us to see the vapor adsorption properties of 1a. An interesting uptake profile was observed for MeOH at 293 K (a). During the initial adsorption process, the isotherm shows a type I curve and then suddenly rises at point A (P/P 0 ∼ 0.39) and attains a saturated level at point B (P/P 0 ∼ 0.92). In the desorption process, MeOH molecules are gradually released until point C (P/P 0 ∼ 0.08), and then the desorption drops immediately; thus, the adsorption/desorption isotherm shows a large hysteresis curve. The amounts of MeOH molecules adsorbed per Cd2+ in the framework are approximately 0.82 (point A), 2.45 (point B), and 1.69 (point C) (b). The initial type I uptake can be considered as the coordination of methanol to the Cd2+ center, and thus, a structural transformation occurs because of conversion of CdO5N to CdO5N­(MeOH). After point A, additional MeOH molecules fill the pore as guest molecules. The desorption is accompanied by a structural change based on the release of loosely bound and coordinated MeOH molecules, and thus, a large hysteresis or different desorption path can be correlated to the structural change and corresponding barrier during the desorption of MeOH molecules. At 298 K, the water vapor adsorption profile of 1a shows a type I profile until P/P 0 ∼ 0.45 with an uptake amount 65 mL/g (∼1.07 molecules/formula), and after that, it rises sharply to reach a final uptake amount of 292 mL/g (4.84 molecules/formula) (b). The first step clearly indicates that the water molecule coordinates to the metal center, and this leads to transformation of the CdO5N → CdO6N core. In the second step, water molecules fill the pores and probably form hydrogen-bonded clusters. The desorption path clearly makes a hysteresis loop because of strong hydrogen bond association of the water molecules.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as supplied without further purification. Cd(ClO4)2⋅H2O and 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane were obtained from Aldrich Co., and benzene-1,4-dicarboxylic acid was obtained from Tokyo Kasei Industrial. Elemental analysis was conducted on a Flash EA 1112 series, Thermo Finnigan instrument. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was conducted with a Rigaku Instrument TG8120 apparatus in a nitrogen atmosphere. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) data were collected on a Rigaku RINT-2200HF diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation. The obtained PXRD pattern for 1a (desolvated 1) was indexed with TREOR 90. Cell parameters of 1a were as follows: triclinic, a = 9.322(9) Å, b = 7.157(5) Å, c = 10.69(2) Å, α = 100.8(1)°, β = 103.8(8)°, γ = 94.2(1)°, V = 675.16 Å3.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure Description of {[Cd(bpe)0.5(bdc)(H2O)]⋅EtOH} n  (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis demonstrated that compound 1 crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group and is a 3D porous coordination polymer containing heptacoordinated Cd2+ centers ( and ). Each heptacoordinated Cd2+ metal center is connected to three different bdc linkers through carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2-O5), one bpe (N1), and one H2O molecule (O1), residing in a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal environment (). Interestingly, the carboxylate group (O2 and O3) of one of the bdc linkers acts as a chelating bidentate ligand, and the other (O4 and O5) functions as a chelating as well as μ-oxo bridging ligand. Therefore, each bdc linker acts as a bridging tridentate ligand. Such a type of ligation creates a Cd2(μ-O)2 cluster, acting as a secondary building unit (SBU) in the structure. Each of these SBUs is connected to four other SBUs by four bdc linkers to generate two-dimensional rectangular sheets lying on the crystallographic ab plane (a). Such 2D sheets are connected by the bpe linkers to form a 3D microporous framework having one-dimensional channels along the c-axis (dimensions of 5.4 Å × 4.4 Å) (b,c). These 1D channels are occupied by the ethanol molecules that are in the proximity of the coordinated (O1) water molecules and thus form strong H-bonds [O1(w)⋅⋅⋅O6(EtOH), 2.717(7) Å] (Figure S1). The H-bonding interactions play a very essential role in the overall conformation and stability of the 3D microporous framework. The Cd2+-O and Cd2+-N bond lengths are in the range of 2.273(5)-2.672(6) and 2.283(5) Å, respectively (Table S1). The degree of distortion from an ideal pentagonal bipyramidal geometry is reflected in the transoid and cisoid angles, which are 133.09(9)-169.91(9)° and 51.90(9)-114.12(9)°, respectively. The deviation of Cd2+ from the mean plane formed by the equatorial atoms is 0.311(2) Å, and the maximal deviation of the equatorial oxygen atom is 0.803(1) Å. The void volume calculated after removal of the coordinated and guest solvent molecules was found to be 22.0% of the total cell volume. Topology analysis by TOPOS shows a binodal (2,6)-connected net with Schläfi symbol {812.123}{8}3 (d).

Thermal Stability

From the TG analysis of compound 1, we found that the guest ethanol and coordinated water molecules can be completely removed at ~80 °C (observed, 14.3%; calculated, 14.8%), and after removal of solvents, the resultant {Cd(bpe)0.5(bdc)} n  (3) is stable up to 290 °C (Figure S3). Further heating gradually decomposes the compound. In the case of compound 2 also, the guest and coordinated solvent molecules are removed at 80 °C (observed, 11.6%; calculated, 12.8%) (Figure S3).

Permanent Porosity: Selective Sorption of O2 over N2 

To check the porous property of compound 1a, N2, O2 (77 K), and CO2 (195 K) gas adsorption measurements were taken. Although compound 1a contains sufficient window dimensions to allow the diffusion of N2 (3.64 Å), it shows a very small amount of N2 uptake (25 mL at 101.325 kPa) at 77 K (a). This is probably due to a higher diffusion barrier imposed on the 1D channel after desolvation and the corresponding structural contraction. It is noteworthy that measurement of O2 at 77 K reveals the steep uptake in low-pressure regions and saturates at ~20 kPa with an uptake amount of 87 mL/g (~12.43 wt %) (a). This suggests that the framework is microporous in nature. The final uptake amount of N2 at ~20 kPa is only 1.5 wt %. Such a huge uptake difference (selectivity factor of ~10) in a low-relative pressure region makes this framework highly selective toward O2 over N2. The amounts of adsorption of N2 and O2 per Cd2+ atom calculated from the Langmuir analyses are 0.3 and 1.3, respectively. Apart from preferential O2 adsorption over N2, the CO2 (kinetic diameter of ~3.4 Å) adsorption profile at 195 K shows interesting features (b). The isotherm shows a two-step uptake and also a distinct hysteresis in adsorption and desorption profile. There are two steps at relative pressures of 0.05 and 0.12 as realized from a logarithmic scale plot, and at P/P 0 ~ 0.96, the final uptake amount is 75 mL/g. In addition, at 273 K CO2 uptake profile also shows a distinct stepwise uptake with a final uptake amount of 23 mL/g (Figure S5). This stepwise adsorption again reflects the structural flexibility associated with CO2 adsorption as the CO2 molecule can interact with the pore surface decorated with carboxylate oxygen and an aromatic π-cloud from bpe and bdc linkers. This type of stepwise uptake of CO2 is not very common and also very important in terms of separation purposes. 

Solvent Vapor Adsorption

The permanent porosity of 1a and structural transformation observed upon exposure to water, methanol, and other solvents lead us to see the vapor adsorption properties of 1a. An interesting uptake profile was observed for MeOH at 293 K (a). During the initial adsorption process, the isotherm shows a type I curve and then suddenly rises at point A (P/P 0 ~ 0.39) and attains a saturated level at point B (P/P 0 ~ 0.92). In the desorption process, MeOH molecules are gradually released until point C (P/P 0 ~ 0.08), and then the desorption drops immediately; thus, the adsorption/desorption isotherm shows a large hysteresis curve. The amounts of MeOH molecules adsorbed per Cd2+ in the framework are approximately 0.82 (point A), 2.45 (point B), and 1.69 (point C) (b). The initial type I uptake can be considered as the coordination of methanol to the Cd2+ center, and thus, a structural transformation occurs because of conversion of CdO5N to CdO5N(MeOH). After point A, additional MeOH molecules fill the pore as guest molecules. The desorption is accompanied by a structural change based on the release of loosely bound and coordinated MeOH molecules, and thus, a large hysteresis or different desorption path can be correlated to the structural change and corresponding barrier during the desorption of MeOH molecules. At 298 K, the water vapor adsorption profile of 1a shows a type I profile until P/P 0 ~ 0.45 with an uptake amount 65 mL/g (~1.07 molecules/formula), and after that, it rises sharply to reach a final uptake amount of 292 mL/g (4.84 molecules/formula) (b). The first step clearly indicates that the water molecule coordinates to the metal center, and this leads to transformation of the CdO5N → CdO6N core. In the second step, water molecules fill the pores and probably form hydrogen-bonded clusters. The desorption path clearly makes a hysteresis loop because of strong hydrogen bond association of the water molecules.
